question.body: If you were going to learn to play an instrument like the flute or trumpet, you would expect which of the following to increase?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Your inspiratory reserve volume would increase but when it increases so will your vital capacity.
Incorrect. Your expiratory reserve volume would increase but when it increases so will your vital capacity.
Incorrect. Your vital capacity would increase but in order to increase your vital capacity you must also increase your inspiratory reserve and expiratory reserve volumes.
Correct. All of the above would increase as your body became more adapted to large amounts of air coming in and being forced out of your lungs.

part.hint: Think which lines would have to increase if you were continually blowing into an instrument.

question.body: According to this graph vital capacity is equal to:

response.feedback: Incorrect. The total lung capacity already includes the residual volume.
Correct. The vital capacity is equal to the total lung capacity minus the residual volume. This will represent the maximum amount of air a person can expel from his or her lungs.
Incorrect. The vital capacity is equal to the Inspiratory reserve volume plus the expiratory reserve volume plus the tidal volume.
Incorrect. The vital capacity is equal to the Inspiratory reserve volume plus the expiratory reserve volume plus the tidal volume.
